ranked_diseases.explanation: Classic presentation with status epilepticus, myoclonus, global developmental delay, and hypotonia. Onset typically in infancy with normal early development followed by regression.
Features myoclonus, status epilepticus, and developmental delays. The combination of myoclonic seizures with hypotonia is characteristic.
Early-onset epileptic encephalopathy with status epilepticus, severe developmental delays, and hypotonia. Nystagmus can be present.
Beyond Dravet syndrome, SCN1A mutations can cause various epileptic encephalopathies with myoclonus, status epilepticus, and developmental delays.
Features multiple seizure types including myoclonic, status epilepticus, intellectual disability, and hypotonia. Age of onset fits.
Prominent myoclonus with epilepsy and progressive neurological decline. However, typically later onset than this patient.
Early-onset epileptic encephalopathy with profound developmental delays, hypotonia, and various seizure types including myoclonus.
Early-onset seizures, severe developmental delays, hypotonia, and motor impairments. Can include myoclonus and nystagmus.
